elements.title: Jex Blackmore (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Jex Blackmore, an American pro-choice activist and Satanist, performed art with 100 pounds (45 kg) of rotten fruit (pictured) before their second abortion?

elements.title: I Feel It Coming (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the music video for the Weeknd's "I Feel It Coming" takes inspiration from people entombed in volcanic ash from the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD?

elements.title: Akihiko Kondo (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Akihiko Kondo "married" Hatsune Miku, a fictional character?

elements.title: In a World... (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Lake Bell made her directorial debut, In a World..., after no one else would direct it?

elements.title: Enoch Edgar Hume (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Enoch Edgar Hume was presented as a candidate for election to the Kentucky House of Representatives without his knowledge?

elements.title: Qision (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Jewish villagers of Qision dedicated an inscription for the salvation of Roman emperor Septimius Severus and his family?

elements.title: Andrei Muntean (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that gymnast Andrei Muntean was Romania's first Youth Olympic Games champion?

elements.title: In the Darkest of Nights, Let the Birds Sing (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a song from the EP In the Darkest of Nights, Let the Birds Sing, written in response to the cancer diagnosis of singer Mark Foster's uncle, was played for him before his death?

elements.title: Karen B. Westerfield Tucker (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Karen B. Westerfield Tucker, who both edited and contributed to The Oxford History of Christian Worship, also served as a dog show judge?
